div.p: VPRS 5834/P0/1, inward correspondence p. 53, VA 1411 Industrial and Technological Museum, Public Record Office, Victoria.

In accordance with your wish, dear Dr Bleasdale, I beg to point out what during the remainder of the year would be the work for the phytologic section of the industrial museum. To place into glass-vessels or into other suitable vehicles a number of medicinal substances, all in select specimens, also named resins, gums, and other exudations from various plants, further vegetable dyes, paper material, woods used by musical instrument-makers, turners, cabinet-makers and other artisans, besides models if some fruits and other vegetable articles, natural fruits of singular kinds &c. These articles are stored up in my laboratory and can best there be worked up or put into order; they require shaping, placing into glass or wood &c, also at least temporary labeling. Furthermore numerous other vegetable articles now already placed into the museum, but utterly unfit to remain there in their unclean, disorderly and partly even not properly named state, would need to come to my laboratory, if my own convenience and economy of time is to be studied, to put these things into order under my professional supervision. I am accustomed to pay about £14 a month to an operator in my laboratory, and this sum would suffice so far for the exclusive employment of one experienced and reliable person, as a few orphan-boys can be found to do some of the more manual work. For Oct., Nov. and Dec. the expenditure would altogether be £42. If to this are added £8 for glass bottles, labels &c, it would bring up the total to £50. I should be glad if the Committee of the industrial Museum would grant early permission of my sending for the articles above referred to as requiring to be temporarily removed from the Museum for being put into order.
